message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A lump that is firm, painless, and without skin changes, nipple discharge, or axillary adenopathy is less likely to be cancerous. An ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in this case as it is less expensive, less invasive, and less likely to involve radiation exposure compared to a mammogram or magnetic resonance imaging. If the ultrasound shows a suspicious finding, then a biopsy is necessary to confirm or rule out cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. For a young patient with a palpable breast mass without any other concerning symptoms, the next step in the workup is performing an ultrasound. Mammogram and MRI can also be used in some cases, but ultrasound is often the first step. A core biopsy may be considered if the ultrasound is inconclusive or if the mass appears suspicious.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient is young and has no family history of breast cancer, ultrasound is the best initial imaging modality. A mammogram may be ordered later if necessary. MRI is not recommended for initial evaluation. If the ultrasound reveals a suspicious mass, a core biopsy may be performed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ultrasound is the initial imaging of choice in any patient presenting with a breast lump. Mammogram and MRI may have a role in further evaluation or screening, but ultrasound should be done first. Ultrasound-guided core biopsy may be necessary if the ultrasound findings are suspicious.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. According to the American College of Radiology, ultrasound is the recommended first imaging test for evaluating breast masses in women under 30 years old because they have denser breast tissue. Mammography can be considered for patients over 30 years old or with suspicious findings on ultrasound. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and biopsy may be used for further evaluation as needed but are not necessary as the initial step. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in the workup of this patient is to perform an ultrasound.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ultrasound is the initial imaging modality in women under 30 with a breast lump due to its high sensitivity and lack of ionizing radiation. Mammography is usually recommended for women over 30, while MRI is reserved for high-risk women or when more detailed imaging is needed. Core biopsy may be necessary if the ultrasound is inconclusive or if there is a high suspicion for malignancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Since the patient is under 30 years old, the recommended initial imaging modality is ultrasound. A mammogram is not typically performed in younger women due to higher risk of false positives. MRI may be considered for further evaluation after an ultrasound or biopsy, but is not the initial step. A core biopsy may be necessary if the ultrasound is suspicious or inconclusive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Ultrasound is the most appropriate first step in the workup of a patient with a breast lump. It can help differentiate between a solid mass and a cystic lesion. Mammogram and MRI may be used to further evaluate the mass, but ultrasound is the initial step. Referral for an ultrasound-guided core biopsy may be necessary if the ultrasound reveals a suspicious mass.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A breast lump in a young and healthy woman is usually benign, and ultrasound is the most appropriate next step in the workup. Mammogram and MRI are usually reserved for older women or if the ultrasound is inconclusive. A referral for a biopsy may be necessary if the ultrasound shows concerning features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is young and has no family history of breast cancer, making it less likely for the mass to be cancerous. Ultrasound is the preferred initial imaging modality for evaluating breast masses in young women because it is noninvasive, radiation-free, and has high sensitivity for detecting breast masses. Mammogram is less sensitive in young women due to their denser breast tissue. MRI and ultrasound-guided core biopsy may be considered if the ultrasound is inconclusive.
